data.title: 6 unexpected revelations from Padma Lakshmi's memoir that shocked the world
data.meta_description: As the Indian-origin author, model and TV host turns 46 today, here's a look at 5 startling revelations by Padma Laksmi that took the world by surprise.
data.text:
When model, author, actress, TV host and philanthropist Padma Lakshmi released her memoir earlier this year, the buzz around it refused to die for quite some time.

The reason? The series of startling revelations that made up its content.

Titled Love, Loss And What We Ate, the memoir houses vivid details about her relationship with celebrated novelist Salman Rushdie, her battle with Endometriosis and how being sexually abused at the age of seven transformed her life.

Padma Lakshmi and Salman Rushdie in happier times. Photo: Reuters

advertisement

As the popular Top Chef host turns 46 today, here's a look at six shocking revelations from her book that came as a surprise to many.

On Salman Rushdie

The whirlwind romance between author Salman Rushdie and Padma Lakshmi was for the entire world to see--so was their subsequent divorce. Having met at a party in 1999, Rushdie, then 51, and Padma Lakshmi who was 28 at the time, exchanged vows in 2004.

The couple ended up divorcing each other in 2007, the reasons for which Lakshmi later penned down in her memoir, Love, Loss and What We Ate.

1. According to Lakshmi, her getting diagnosed with Endometriosis was one of the major reasons behind her failed marriage with novelist Rushdie. The disease, which is caused when a tissue that normally grows inside the uterus grows outside it, resulted in a lack of physical intimacy between the two--which made Rushdie refer to her as a "bad investment". Lakshmi also hints how--to a certain extent--Rushdie was insensitive towards her disease and took her inability to have sex (due to Endometriosis) as rejection.

Lakshmi's memoir. Picture courtesy: Instagram/ Padma Lakshmi

2. The memoir also had Lakshmi reveal that Booker-Prize-winner Rushdie used to be disappointed each time the Nobel Prize for Literature was awarded to some other author.

3. Love, Loss and What We Ate also sheds light on how Rushdie "seduced" her with his words.

On being sexually abused at the age of 7

4. Host of popular show Top Chef, Lakshmi also mentions how one of her father's close relatives sexually abused her at the age of seven.

"One night, I woke up to his hand in my underpants. He took my hand and placed it inside his briefs. I don't know how many times it happened before, since I suspect I slept through some incidents," the memoir has her write.

Lakshmi as a child. Picture courtesy: Instagram/ Padma Lakshmi

Also Read: Urinated behind bed after being sexually abused at the age of seven, reveals Padma Lakshmi

5. As disturbing as the sexual abuse was in itself, her parents' reaction to it was equally, if not more, shocking.

The incident came to light when her mother discovered that she had "urinated behind her bed in a sign of distress". Lakshmi revealed how after confronting her parents about the same, she was sent off to Madras.

"In retrospect, however, he should have been the one to go," she writes. "Years later, in tears, my mother would acknowledge this grave mistake."

On daughter Krishna's father

6. Reportedly, Lakshmi also admits to not knowing the name of her now six-year-old daughter Krishna's father when she was first informed about her pregnancy.

Padma Lakshmi with daughter Krishna. Picture courtesy: Instagram/ Padma Lakshmi
